titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Catharine T. Patterson Collection of Walter Crane
Patterson (Catharine T.) collection of Walter Crane
titlestmt.author: by Sandra Markham and Francesca Tancini

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 05:44

did.unittitle: Catharine T. Patterson Collection of Walter Crane

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection contains original sketches, drawings, proof sheets, autograph manuscripts, and autograph letters from and to the English illustrator Walter Crane.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Correspondence, 1876-1914. II. Writings and Graphic Material, 1867-1913. III. Catharine T. Patterson Collection Files, 1920-1957.

bioghist.head: Catharine T. Patterson (1874-1963)
bioghist.p: Catharine Tinker Patterson was born in 1874 in Weymouth, Massachusetts, the daughter of the Reverend Anson Phelps Tinker (1844-1886, Yale 1868) and Martha Jane White Tinker (1846-1880). An 1897 graduate of Emerson College of Oratory in Boston, Massachusetts, she taught school in Minnesota and Massachusetts before joining the faculty at Emerson in 1900. From 1906 until 1917 she taught at Hartford Public High School in Hartford, Connecticut, and in 1917 settled in New York City when she married George Lewis Patterson (1869-1942), founder and president of Stanley & Patterson, manufacturers of electrical signal apparatus. After her husband's death, Catharine Patterson returned to Connecticut to live near her brother Chauncey Brewster Tinker (1876-1963, Yale BA 1899, MA 1901, PhD 1902), professor of English at Yale University from 1903 to 1945 and the first keeper of rare books at Yale University Library. She died in Hartford on September 11, 1963, and was buried in Evergreen Cemetery in Portland, Maine, with her husband and his first wife Alice Carter Patterson (1869-1915).

In an essay published in The Christian Science Monitor on July 26, 1941, Catharine Patterson described a life of collecting that began with the buttons, stones, and seashells she and her brother had saved as children. Their early adult lives took them in different directions, but they developed their passion for Walter Crane's work while traveling together in England where, she wrote, "the spell of the Pre-Raphaelites was upon us. Everything belonging to the Brotherhood beckoned us." They began by studying the paintings, drawings, furniture, stained glass, and other decorative arts created by Burne-Jones, Millais, and Rossetti, and made a special pilgrimage to Kelmscott House, the home and workshop of William Morris in the London suburb of Hammersmith. Through Morris they discovered the decorative book work of Crane, his friend and follower, in particular that which illustrated the stories the Tinkers had loved so much as children. The siblings set out to acquire books, manuscripts, letters, original drawings, textiles, and other items related to Crane, and to lend selections from their collection to public exhibitions. The earliest known loan was to the Brooklyn Museum in 1923 when "an extensive collection of books and prints and an original drawing by Walter Crane, from the collection of Mrs. George L. Patterson" were shown. A 1939 New York Public Library exhibition described their Crane collection as being "made by [Mrs. George L. Patterson] and her brother, Professor Chauncey Tinker of Yale University, who acquired a large part of it from a son of Walter Crane." The collection was shown again in 1953 at Princeton University, three years prior to its arrival at the Yale University Library.

Catharine Patterson wrote that she was delighted when she found that the collection, which she and her brother had always intended to donate to Yale, had a counterpart at Harvard University in the Caroline Miller Parker Collection of Works by Walter Crane, formed by Caroline Parker (1874-1922) and given to Harvard in 1928 by her husband Augustin H. Parker. Today the Beinecke Library's Catharine T. Patterson Collection of Walter Crane stands as the third largest collection of Crane material after the Walter Crane Archive at the University of Manchester in England and the Parker Collection at the Houghton Library.

bioghist.head: Walter Crane (1845-1915)
bioghist.p: Walter Crane (1845-1915), English author and illustrator best known for his work in children's literature. Among the most important illustrators of the nineteenth century, Crane was also a painter, essayist, and decorative artist who created designs for wallpapers, tiles, printed textiles, posters, stained glass, embroideries, and pottery. His formal education consisted of an apprenticeship served with the wood engraver and illustrator W. J. Linton from 1858 to 1862; later he was a founder of The Art-Workers' Guild (1884) and a founder and first president of The Arts and Crafts Exhibition Society (1888).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Catharine T. Patterson Collection of Walter Crane. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Prior to 2016, the manuscripts and artwork related to Walter Crane were kept together as one collection and primarily filed under the call number MS Vault Crane. When the material was processed in 2016 it was decided to extract and reassemble the Catharine T. Patterson's Collection of Walter Crane (under call number GEN MSS 1386), and to describe the remaining Crane material—items purchased by the library or received as gifts from other donors—separately as the Walter Crane Collection (under GEN MSS 1418).

This finding aid was produced from Catharine Patterson's inventories, library correspondence files, and a previously existing card set in the library's Manuscripts Catalog. The information drawn from those sources was greatly enhanced through the efforts of the Crane scholar Francesca Tancini, an A. Bartlett Giamatti Fellow at Beinecke Library in 2015, who examined all the Walter Crane material in the library's collection and cataloged the original (non-print) items. Many of her descriptions and narratives form the basis of this finding aid, and the library is enormously grateful for her careful work.
Catharine Patterson's printed collection of more than 200 books by Crane were described separately in the library's online catalog.
Former call numbers: MS Vault Crane, MS Vault Shelves Crane, and J18 C8512 892Ha, Z8198.4 M37 (LC)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection contains original sketches, drawings, proof sheets, autograph manuscripts, and autograph letters from and to the British illustrator Walter Crane. Prominent material includes correspondence, drawings, and proofs related to Crane's commission to illustrate A Wonder Book for Girls and Boys , by Nathaniel Hawthorne (Boston: Houghton, Mifflin & Company, 1893), and a group of unpublished illustrated storybooks he created for his children Beatrice, Lionel, and Lancelot. Other correspondents include Crane patrons Ethel Alec-Tweedie and Catharine Lorillard Wolfe, and colleagues such as Elkin Mathews, William Morris, Charles Rowley, and David Croal Thomson. Also present is an autographed portrait photograph of Crane by Elliott & Fry of London, a painted silk fan, embroidered and batik-dyed textiles, and a full-color preparatory drawing of his Vineyard wallpaper pattern. The collection also holds a bookplate designed for Crane by Henry Ospovat (1877-1909).

Series III consists of files holding Catharine T. Patterson's documentation of her collection. They contain correspondence with dealers and institutions, inventories, research notes, and clippings, as well as her writings on Crane and on her collection. Also present is her copy of A Bibliography of First Editions of Books Illustrated by Walter Crane , by Gertrude C. E. Massé (London: The Chelsea Publishing Co., 1923), with her annotations to record her acquisitions of books and related drawings.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Catharine T. Patterson Collection of Walter Crane is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning production of The Wonder Book , and transporting Crane's personal property.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ten letters and two postcards from Crane to Mathews; two letters from Mathews to Crane, most regarding the publication of Crane's Renascence (London: Elkin Mathews, 1891).

did.unittitle: Letters from Mary Frances Crane and Lionel F. Crane

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter from Morris to Crane arranging for a meeting to discuss illustrations for Morris's The Story of the Glittering Plain .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes printed "at home" card (1898-1899) and invitation to the wedding of Beatrice Crane to Sydney Jeffree (1900).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning pirated edition of his The Baby's Opera .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning his proposed articles for the Art Journal , his role as English delegate to the First International Exhibition of Modern Art at Turin, and comments on the Royal Watercolor Society's presentation to William Callow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning exhibitions of Crane's work at museums in New York and Boston.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning Whiteford's offer of Italian embroideries and costumes to the Victoria and Albert Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six autograph letters, signed.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Manuscripts and Artwork, Printed Material, and Other Material.

did.unittitle: Aladdin, or The Wonderful Lamp (London & New York: George Routledge and Sons, [1875])

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One drawing, graphite and ink on paper, of Aladdin and his lamp (p. 2); on verso, graphite sketch of a procession scene (p. 4).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One preparatory drawing, gouache and Chinese white on brown paper, for an allegorical silver cup realized in collaboration with the illustrator George Du Maurier (1834-1896). The cup was produced by Hunt & Roskell, manufacturing and retail jewellers and silversmiths in London.

did.unittitle: The Baby's Opera (London & New York: George Routledge and Sons, [1876])

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five drawings, watercolor on paper; illustrating the songs "Here We Go Round the Mulberry Bush" (p. 11), "How Does My Lady's Garden Grow" (p. 15), "Little Bo-Peep" (p. 37), "I Had a Little Nut Tree" (p. 45), and "Jack & Jill" (p. 53).

[Note: Francesca Tancini questions their authenticity (to Crane's hand); the drawings are reversed when compared with the finished result and with the original drawings at the British Museum, Whitworth Art Gallery, and the Opie Collection at Bodleian Library.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One drawing, gouache on brown paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thirty-one graphite and watercolor drawings pasted into a sketchbook. Inscribed on flyleaf: "These drawings were made for my sister Beatrice when a little girl - date 1880 - by my late Father Walter Crane R. W. S. signed Lionel Crane." Known as: A Book for Beatrice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fifty-one graphite and watercolor drawings pasted into an album with boards covered with flowered paper. Attached is Lionel F. Crane's typewritten note, signed and dated "Melcombe House Montpellier Row | October 16/40": "This is an original book, drawn and written by my Father, Walter Crane, containing 56 drawings [sic], one of the famous black books, done for us when we were children and cleaned and restored and mounted by my wife, Winifred Crane, Signed Lionel F. Crane | Oct 16/40." Some of the drawings could have been colored or altered in some way by Lionel and Winifred Crane.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thirty-six graphite and watercolor drawings pasted into a sketchbook. Leaf laid in: "This book was done by my late Father…for me when a child signed Lionel F. Crane."

did.unittitle: The Forty Thieves (London & New York: John Lane, [1898])

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One drawing for the cover; red and black ink on paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph poem, possibly for an unpublished book "His Majesty the Baby."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six loose drawings, graphite and ink on paper, inserted in a blank bound sketchbook; also known as "His Majesty's Servants."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sixteen ink and watercolor drawings in an oblong sketchbook bound in gray paper boards; inscribed by Crane on inside front cover: "Lancelot Crane 1890."

did.unittitle: "The House that Jack Built up to Date"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four leaves with autograph manuscript, illustrated, for a skit written by Crane and performed by members of the Art Workers' Guild at Clifford's Inn, January 26, 1904; in tan wrappers.

did.unittitle: Household Stories from the Collection of the Brothers Grimm (London: Macmillan Co., 1882)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One drawing, ink on Bristol board, for "Rapunzel."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Cover design, watercolor on paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seventy-two ink and watercolor drawings tipped into album (99 leaves, 42 of which are uncut), dated on front cover Oct 1884; only partially published in Little Folks (London, 1888). Bound in half cloth, and with Crane's bookplate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thirty-three graphite and watercolor drawings pasted into a sketchbook. Inscribed on flyleaf: "This book was drawn for us when we were children - by my late Father Walter Crane R.W.S. signed Lionel F. Crane." In tan wrappers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sketchbook of 39 leaves with graphite drawings. The first half of the book is designed as a copy book, with Crane's drawings at the top of the sheet and Lionel's copies on the bottom. The second half of the book contains alphabet letters with accompanying images.

did.unittitle: Menu design for a dinner to honor William Poel, December 1, 1912

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ink on card, accompanied by a proof print on blue paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One sketch, graphite and watercolor on tracing paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album bound in boards covered with flowered paper, holding ink and watercolor drawings: 18 drawings for "Mr. Michael Mouse Unfolds his Tale, and "The True Tale of a Mouse, Continued" (17 drawings), "A Bat Sat in a Hat" (8 drawings), and "The History of Bronwen the Brown, Harlech 1887 (15 drawings) for a total of 58 drawings on 70 leaves.

First and second stories published as Michael Mouse Unfolds his Tale, Reproduced from the Original Manuscript in the Collection of Mrs. Catharine T. Patterson (New Haven: Yale University Library, 1956).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Design, gouache on board, for the cover of the University of London Bazaar & Fete booklet, edited by Mrs. Alec-Tweedie; inscribed along lower edge: "This is the original by Walter Crane for my Bazaar booklet. E. Alec-Tweedie."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album of autograph poems with vignette illustrations (dated 1867-1872) and a graphite portrait of Mary Frances Andrews Crane (dated June 25, 1881) tipped in on verso of leaf 1; 140 leaves (64-140 blank). Bound in vellum, with Crane's bookplate. Several of the poems were published in Crane's Renascence (London: Elkin Mathews, 1891).

did.unittitle: Renascence, A Book of Verse (London: Elkin Mathews, 1891)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph poem on paper mounted on board, accompanied by Crane's autograph dated April 26, 1893.

did.unittitle: Headpiece and tailpiece, ink on paper
The Shepheard's Calender , by Edmund Spenser (New York and London: Harper Brothers, 1898)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Watercolor and Chinesea white on board.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Watercolor and Chinesea white on paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For title pages and decorative borders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fourteen graphite and watercolor drawings pasted on 16 leaves in a sketchbook, undated (date on title page is not contemporary with drawings), supposedly [1881]. Inscribed on title page" "These original drawings were done by my late father...signed Lionel F. Crane." Bound in gray wrappers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Four sketches, ink and graphite on board, for a six-panel mural frieze designed for Catharine Lorillard Wolfe as a room decoration for Vinland, her Scandinavian-style house at Newport, Rhode Island. The theme was taken from Henry Wadsworth Longfellow's poem "The Skeleton in Armour," which was inspired by Longfellow's viewing of an ancient stone tower in Newport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Notebook of graphite and watercolor drawings: 40 leaves (one of which is cut off, and first and last leaves pasted to cover) with autograph notes, sketches and drawings, dated: January 21, April 30 1863. Contains several preparatory drawings for Mrs. Henry Wood, Mrs. Halliburton's Troubles and one preparatory drawing for St. Agnes Eve ; drawings copied from Henry Shaw, Dresses and Decorations of the Middle Ages , Thomas Hope, The Costumes of the Ancients , and Charles Wilkes, Narrative of the United States Exploring Expedition . Bound in three-quarter roan.

did.unittitle: Spenser's Faerie Queene. A Poem in Six Books (London: G. Allen, 1894-1897)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six graphite sketches for illustrations, two ink drawings for headings for Book II, Canto IX and Book VI, Canto IX, and one ink drawing for the frontispiece, Book II, Canto X, Stanza 70 (p. 471: "But Guyon all this while his booke did read…"); Crane used himself as model in the latter drawing.

did.unittitle: Stories of Old; or, Bible Narratives Suited to the Capacity of Young Children , by Caroline Hadley (London: Smith, Elder & Co. 1863)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drawings for "The Story of the Birth of Moses" ("Moses in the Bulrushes") and "The Destruction of Pharaoh" ("Pharaoh's chariots and his host hath he cast into the sea"); ink on paper mounted on paper. The drawings were not used in that publication or in the American issue (New York, Sheldon & Co., 1863).

did.unittitle: "Time's Show, Undoubtedly the Greatest on Earth"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven ink and watercolor drawings, including cover, for an unpublished children's book, in an oblong sketchbook with seventeen leaves. Inscribed on front flyleaf: "These drawings are by my late Father Walter Crane R. W. S. Signed Lionel F. Crane."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Design for cover (London & New York: John Lane, [1897]), ink and watercolor on paper, and one illustration (London & New York: George Routledge and Sons, [1874]) of "a great she-bear came up, and carried off one child), ink on Bristol board. On verso of cover drawing: "This is an original drawing by my late Father Walter Crane signed Lionel F. Crane."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Preparatory drawing in chalk, gouache, and Chinese white on brown paper, for "Vineyard" (also known as "Peacock and Vine with Poppies") produced by Jeffrey & Co.

did.unittitle: The Vision of Dante , by Elizabeth Harrison (Chicago: Chicago Kindergarten College, 1894)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "Dante and the Three Beasts" and "The Angel in the boat approaching Dante and Virgil on the short"; ink on card.

did.unittitle: A Wonder Book for Girls and Boys , by Nathaniel Hawthorne (Boston: Houghton, Mifflin Company, 1893)
Two sketches on tracing paper, one gouache drawing, and a printed version for "Edition de luxe" half-title.
Thirty-one watercolor, ink, and Chinese white drawings for headpieces, tailpieces, and a half-title.
Twenty-six illustration proofs printed on watercolor paper; one with hand-applied color
Five illustration proofs printed in color

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by Crane for Gardner Teall and Harry Elkins Widener; accompanied by a proof print of a bookplate designed for Crane by Henry Ospovat (1877–1909).

did.unittitle: "Caliban," from Eight Illustrations to Shakespeare's Tempest

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Designed by Walter Crane, engraved & printed by Duncan C. Dallas (London: J. M. Dent, 1893). Accompanied by printed title page and the Dallastype plate of "Caliban," and the edition statement page signed by Crane and Dallas.

did.unittitle: Columbia's Courtship: a Picture History of the United States in Twelve Emblematic Designs (Boston: L. Prang Co., 1892)
